After an appeal by McCullough, Illinois state's attorney Richard Schmack launched a six-month investigation that found what he calls "clear and convincing evidence" that McCullough is innocent. That timeline was later changed by police, and Schmack says documents—including phone and Air Force records—supporting McCullough's alibi were wrongly not allowed at his trial. A friend of the kidnapped girl picked McCullough out of a photo lineup when the case was reopened. But his was the only non-yearbook photo in the lineup, and she picked a different man out of a photo lineup 50 years earlier. That info wasn't allowed at McCullough's trial either. No physical evidence was ever found to support McCullough's conviction.

Two recent studies, published by researchers at the University of California, San Diego School of Medicine, have revealed a surprising connection between cigarette smoke and antibiotic-resistant bacteria, particularly MRSA (Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus). These findings highlight the negative impact of smoking on the virulence of MRSA, making it more resistant to antibiotics and more aggressive in causing infections.

In the first study, published in the journal Infection and Immunity, researchers discovered that exposure to cigarette smoke increases the resistance of MRSA by altering its cell walls. This change in the bacteria's structure allows it to better withstand the toxic effects of reactive oxygen species, which are typically used by the immune system to fight off infections. The study found that MRSA exposed to cigarette smoke was four times more resistant to macrophage killing, and its resistance to antimicrobial peptides increased as well.

The second study, led by Dr. Laura Crotty Alexander, also found that e-cigarette vapor, although not as potent as cigarette smoke, still has a similar effect on MRSA, making it more resistant and increasing its ability to invade human cells. Crotty Alexander's team observed that the bacteria's resistance persisted for 24 hours after exposure, suggesting a potential for long-term persistence and transmission.

These findings emphasize the role of cigarette smoke in fueling the growth and resistance of MRSA, highlighting the need for smokers to be aware of the additional risk they face due to this interaction. The researchers suggest that understanding this link could contribute to the development of new strategies to combat antibiotic-resistant infections, as well as potentially influencing public health campaigns to discourage smoking.

In summary, cigarette smoke acts as a catalyst, making MRSA more resistant and harmful, and the increased resistance observed in MRSA exposed to cigarette smoke could have significant implications for the spread and treatment of antibiotic-resistant infections. Both cigarette smoke and e-cigarette vapor can alter the bacteria's cell walls, but cigarette smoke appears to have a more pronounced effect, making it a crucial factor to consider in the battle against antibiotic-resistant超级细菌.
answers: Superbugs such as MRSA are already bad enough. But it turns out that something can make them even nastier: cigarette smoke. Researchers found that antibiotic-resistant bacteria exposed to the smoke became more aggressive and far more difficult to kill, they explain at Eureka Alert. It's almost as if the smoke sets off an alarm that causes the bacteria to strengthen its defenses, explains the Union-Tribune of San Diego. Scientists made the discovery by exposing immune cells to two different batches of MRSA, one normal and one treated with cigarette smoke extract. The bigger the dose of smoke, the bigger the effect, notes Medical Daily. "We already know that smoking cigarettes harms human respiratory and immune cells, and now we've shown that, on the flipside, smoke can also stress out invasive bacteria and make them more aggressive," says lead author Laura Crotty Alexander of UC San Diego. It's a double-whammy: Smokers already have weakened immune systems that make them more susceptible to infectious diseases, and the smoke they inhale seems to make invading pathogens even more dangerous. In this study, the smoke helped MRSA survive longer and kill more mice with pneumonia. (The latest antibiotic-resistant bug to make headlines is a nasty stomach virus.)

The University of Toulouse's Young-Ho Eom led a study analyzing Wikipedia articles to determine the most influential people in the English-language world, as well as globally. The initial findings placed Frank Sinatra at the top, followed by Michael Jackson and Pope Pius XII. The study revealed that the most influential figure, according to 2DRank, was actually Swedish naturalist Carl Linnaeus, known for his work in taxonomy.

The study aimed to investigate if Wikipedia's content was biased towards certain individuals based on factors like gender, time, or location. It discovered that most significant historical figures were born in western countries after the 17th century and were predominantly male. The algorithm seemed to favor Linnaeus due to the abundance of scientific names and their connection to his work.

A separate project from the Internet Archive aims to preserve web pages by archiving them as they are created and updating links to reflect changes or deletions. This effort is part of their "No More 404" initiative, which seeks to fix broken links on the web.

In another study, researchers calculated the world's most influential thinker using Wikipedia's Wikipedia pages. Initial results showed that Linnaeus, the "Father of Taxonomy," topped the list, beating out notable figures like Michael Jackson, the Pope, and historical figures like Hitler and Jesus. The study's success was attributed to the prevalence of scientific names in Wikipedia, particularly in the English language edition.

Overall, the research suggests that while Wikipedia's content can be influenced by factors like language and cultural context, the ranking of influential figures is influenced by the specific methods used, such as the combination of PageRank and CheiRank. The study also highlights the importance of understanding the context and influence of specific fields, as in the case of Linnaeus' influence in taxonomy.
answers: Using methods borrowed from Google, a group of researchers has analyzed all Wikipedia pages and determined that, at least on the English language version of the site, Frank Sinatra is the world's most important person. Second place goes to Michael Jackson, and third to Pope Pius XII. When factoring in all 24 language editions of the online encyclopedia, the team found that Adolf Hitler ranked the most important person, while Michael Jackson was again second and Madonna third, reports the Guardian. "Our analysis shows that most important historical figures across Wikipedia language editions are born in western countries after the 17th century, and are male," the authors write. The researchers combined two algorithms to reach these conclusions. First, Google's PageRank algorithm, which determines a page's importance based on how many other pages link to it. In using PageRank on Wikipedia, the most important person in the world was 18th-century Swedish naturalist Carl Linnaeus, likely because the pages of organism after organism link back to the "father of taxonomy." So the researchers added an algorithm called CheiRank, which determines importance based on the number of outgoing links, the thought being that an important person would himself be connected to other important people, things, and events. Using the two together—an approach they dubbed 2DRank—no one beat out Frank Sinatra on English pages or Adolf Hitler across all language versions. Last year, in a separate study analyzing academic references, one team deemed Karl Marx to be the world's most important scholar, according to the Smithsonian. He hopes the berms will help explain the "insane, utterly unsustainable" construction boom that led to Marden Henge and four other nearby Neolithic monuments, including Stonehenge. "For all the attention that has been lavished on Stonehenge over the years, we may well find out that Marden was where it was really at during the Neolithic," he says. The discovery of a new dinosaur species, Caihong juji, with iridescent feathers resembling those of a hummingbird has been announced. This small dinosaur, about the size of a crow, lived during the Jurassic Period in China and is the first of its kind to have rainbow-colored feathers. The feathers, with their unique four-barbule structure, are believed to have been used for both sexual attraction and possibly for communication, similar to modern birds. The fossilized dinosaur, which had a bird-like head and hindlimbs but lacked the ability to fly, had feathered tails that were similar to those of Archaeopteryx, the earliest known bird.

Caihong's feathers were found to have distinctively arranged, narrow barbs that create a symmetrical vaning pattern on the tail, similar to those seen in birds. The study also revealed nanostructures in the fossilized feathers that are structurally similar to melanosomes found in modern bird feathers, suggesting that the dinosaur's feathers were likely pigmented in a rainbow-like manner.

The significance of these iridescent feathers lies in their potential role in communication and possibly sexual selection, as seen in modern birds. The dinosaur's unique combination of feather characteristics, including its asymmetrical tail feathers, challenges the traditional understanding of feather evolution and suggests that the ability to produce iridescent colors may have been present in early paravians, hinting at a more colorful Jurassic world.

The study's authors, including paleontologists from the University of Texas at Austin and the Chinese Academy of Sciences, emphasize the importance of further research to understand the function and evolution of these feathers in Caihong and other feathered dinosaurs. The dinosaur's scientific name, Caihong juji, reflects its rainbow-like appearance and the significance of its discovery.

Reuters reports that a closer look at the "exquisitely preserved," almost completely intact fossil of a crow-like dinosaur that lived about 161 million years ago revealed that Caihong juji had luminous, brilliantly hued feathers that closely resembled those of hummingbirds. The study in the journal Nature Communications documenting the find explains that "Caihong" means "rainbow" in Mandarin. Scientists think the colorful plumage, which appeared to have covered the bony-crested creature's head, neck, and chest areas, may have kept the dinosaur warm, as well as attracted potential mates; National Geographic compares it to peacock feathers. So how were researchers able to tell what color feathers the creature had from preserved bones? They used high-tech microscopes able to home in on 66 sites on the fossil, detecting tiny cell structures called melanosomes, which underlie pigmentation. Which colors they led to can be found by their shapes, and the melanosomes in Caihong were long and flat like pancakes—similar to those found in hummingbirds, which boast iridescent plumage. Although they can't pick out from the Pantone wheel Caihong's exact colors, researchers say the creature likely sported feathers with a "rainbow glimmer." Study co-author Xing Zu tells National Geographic that Caihong was a predator that spent its days gliding from tree to tree. And "glide" is the operative word, as this dinosaur likely didn't fly: Its feathers were located on its tail, not on its wings like birds, Discover notes. (A study postulated that nearly all dinosaurs had feathers.)

pred: NASA's upcoming mission to study the sun, known as the Parker Solar Probe, has been renamed to honor the late solar astrophysicist Eugene Parker, who predicted the existence of solar wind. The probe will attempt to get within 3.9 million miles of the sun's surface, the closest any spacecraft has ever been, to investigate the sun's corona, which is much hotter than the sun's surface. The mission aims to unravel the mysteries of the sun's heating, solar wind acceleration, and space weather effects. Named after Parker, the Parker Solar Probe is set to revolutionize our understanding of the sun and its impact on Earth, with potential to improve space weather forecasting and protect technological systems from disruptions. The spacecraft will use advanced thermal protection and a 4.5-inch-thick heat shield to withstand the extreme heat and radiation. The mission is expected to provide valuable insights into the physics of stars and space weather, with implications for industries like power grids and air travel. answers: NASA is going to the sun. More specifically, it's launching an unmanned probe next year that will travel closer to the star than any spacecraft has done previously. "It's a spacecraft loaded with technological breakthroughs that will solve many of the largest mysteries about our star," says Nicola Fox of the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory. In less scientific terms, per the Telegraph: "We will finally touch the sun." The nuts and bolts: The mission: The 10-foot probe will launch in July or August of 2018 and eventually get to within 3.7 million miles of the sun, about seven times closer than any previous spacecraft. Eventually, it will be whizzing around the sun at a speed of 450,000 miles per hour, reports CNN. The mission ends in 2025. Corona: The probe will actually fly into the outermost part of the sun's atmosphere, called the corona, per a mission overview at NASA that touts "humanity's first visit to a star." The heat: The probe will rely on a 4.5-inch-thick carbon-composite solar shield to help it withstand temperatures up to 2,550 degrees Fahrenheit, reports Orlando's WKMG. Instruments will remain at room temperature. The name: The probe's name has been changed to the Parker Solar Probe to honor astrophysicist Eugene Parker, who's credited with discovering solar wind. Parker, who turns 90 in June, is a professor emeritus at the University of Chicago, and the Guardian recounts that the theory he put forward in 1958 about a stream of charged particles flowing from the sun was once thought to be "crazy." A first: This is the first time NASA has named a mission after a living scientist. "I'm certainly greatly honored," said the man himself, per Space.com. Two puzzles: Scientists hope to better understand two things in particular: "How is the solar wind accelerated, and why is the ... corona so much hotter than the solar surface?" (It's 3 million degrees Fahrenheit vs. 10,000 degrees Fahrenheit.) Why it matters: Generally, solar storms are relatively harmless when they reach Earth, but these particle bursts occasionally wreak havoc on satellites and here on Earth, and they have the potential to be devastating. "The more we know about how these processes work, the better we can get at predicting when they will happen," writes Loren Grush at the Verge.

But stone tools found in Kenya's Olorgesailie Basin show hominin groups—it's not clear which species is responsible—had developed these more advanced tools approximately 320,000 years ago. An expert not involved in the study says the tools are so "prepared and retouched" they suggest the Middle Stone Age likely started even earlier. What drove it? A black Range Rover, believed to be involved in an altercation at a nearby casino, opened fire on a Maserati, causing it to crash into a taxi that caught fire, resulting in the taxi's explosion. The incident occurred at the intersection of Las Vegas Boulevard and Flamingo Road, a popular location for major hotels like the Bellagio, Caesars Palace, and Bally's. The shooter and the occupants of the Range Rover fled the scene, and police were searching for the vehicle and its occupants, who were contacted in California and neighboring states.

The shooting marked a deviation from the typically peaceful atmosphere of the Las Vegas Strip, which has experienced some violence in recent weeks, but this incident was described as "not a regular occurrence." The taxi driver and the Maserati driver were killed, while the Maserati passenger survived but was injured. The police were investigating the possible trigger for the confrontation and were examining surveillance footage for clues.

The area around the intersection was closed for most of the day as crime scene investigators worked, and witnesses described the scene as surreal, comparing it to a scene from a movie like "Die Hard." The incident raised concerns about safety among tourists, despite the city's reputation for being a relatively safe destination.

The police were looking for a silver Range Rover SUV with tinted windows and dealer plates, believed to be the vehicle responsible for the shooting. The incident disrupted the morning routine for tourists and caused delays for those trying to access the normally bustling Strip. The Las Vegas Convention and Visitors Authority assured visitors that the city remains a safe place to visit.

This shooting adds to a series of violent incidents in the city, including a previous shooting at a parking garage and a stabbing at The Hotel at Mandalay Bay. However, the police maintained that the city is still a safe place for visitors, with officers having made arrests or identified suspects in previous violent incidents. The incident highlighted the contrast between the glamorous image of the Strip and the occasional acts of violence that can occur in the city.
answers: Police in three states are still hunting for a Range Rover whose occupants opened fire on another car on the Vegas Strip this morning and set off a deadly chain reaction. Cops don't know most of the details, but they say it started with a dispute of some kind in one of the nearby hotels, then spilled into the street, reports the Las Vegas Sun. When the Range Rover caught up to a Maserati at a stop light, shots were fired from the SUV that sent the Maserati crashing into a taxi, which exploded upon impact. Three people—the Maserati driver, the taxi driver, and a taxi passenger—were killed, and three others were injured, reports the LA Times. Police are hoping to piece together more details by interviewing a passenger in the Maserati, who was injured in the melee. Earlier reports that gunfire came from both vehicles as part of a moving shootout were incorrect. The AP collects this quote from a tourist visiting from Manchester, England: "This doesn't happen where we come from, not on this scale. We get stabbings, and gang violence, but this is like something out of a movie. Like Die Hard or something."

Her step-grandparents, Leland and Sharon Bowman, were still unaccounted for, and their fate was not confirmed. The search for the plane was challenging due to the rugged terrain, but authorities were able to narrow down the search area based on Autumn's cellphone data and flight patterns. The少年's survival and the assistance from a data trail from her cellphone helped locate the crash site. The Beech A-35 plane, however, had not been found as of Monday night.
answers: A 16-year-old girl in Washington state is bruised and dehydrated but very much alive after surviving a plane crash and a long trek through what authorities describe as some of the state's most rugged terrain. Autumn Veatch was on a small plane with her step-grandparents that crashed after departing Kalispell, Mont., on Saturday afternoon, the Bellingham Herald reports. There was no sign of the plane or its occupants until a motorist found Veatch on State Route 20 yesterday afternoon and took her to a general store, where employees called authorities, the AP reports. She was hospitalized with minor injuries. Her father tells the Herald that after the plane crashed into a mountain, it caught fire and she was unable to get her step-grandparents out. She spent about a day near the plane waiting for rescue before following a stream and then a trail out of the woods, her father says. Friends say both father and daughter are completely overwhelmed. "She did joke that it was a good thing she'd watched all those Survivor shows that she didn't like, but her dad made her watch anyway," a family friend tells the Seattle Times. The news revolves around the controversy surrounding Gibson Guitar and its potential violation of the Lacey Act, a federal law regulating the trade of endangered species wood. In 2011, the company was raided by the Justice Department over allegations of using illegally sourced wood, particularly from Madagascar, which led to the seizure of equipment and production. The U.S. government claims that the company was aware of the risks associated with the wood's origin and still proceeded to import it. Gibson denies the accusations, stating that their purchases were legal and that they have provided documentation to support their claims.

The situation has raised concerns among the guitar industry, with some arguing that the Lacey Act, which requires end-users to verify the legality of their wood supply chains, could potentially affect guitar makers who have used wood sourced before the law's enforcement. The Environmental Investigation Agency's director, Andrea Johnson, supports the act but acknowledges the need to adapt to the new regulations.

The news also highlights the donation of crawl data by Alexa Internet to the Internet Archive since 1996, which contributes to the Internet Archive's Wayback Machine, preserving web content over time. This aspect of the story serves as a parallel to the legal battle between Gibson and the government, demonstrating the intersection of technology and environmental regulation.
answers: Allegations of illegal wood imports prompted the Justice Department to raid Gibson Guitar facilities in Tennessee last week. NPR aired the complicated story involving the 100-year old Lacey Act, which prohibits imports of endangered species, including plants, into the US. No formal charges have been pressed, but it appears the issue lies with Gibson possibly importing banned Madagascar ebony. Gibson insists the wood confiscated by marshals was legally acquired rosewood from India. Adding some gusto to the story, right-leaning sites assert that Gibson rival CF Martin uses the same wood in some of its guitars, but the company was never investigated. The Landmark Report thinks that's fishy, given that Martin's CEO is a Democratic donor and Gibson's CEO is a GOP backer. Raising the octave even higher, it is possible Michelle Obama ran afoul of the Lacey Act when she presented France's Carla Bruni with a Gibson guitar that may have contained banned wood. However the story plays out, many are frustrated with the retroactive aspect of the law. "It's a nightmare," says a dealer. "I can't help it if they used Brazilian rosewood on almost every guitar made prior to 1970."

The conflict has resulted in the deaths of 19 Palestinians and three Israelis, with many more injured. Schools in both Israel and Gaza have been closed, and residents are living in fear of rocket attacks. The Israeli military has struck over 250 targets in Gaza, while the Iron Dome missile defense system has intercepted 97 rockets. The international community, including the UK, supports Israel's right to self-defense but also calls for a de-escalation and a resolution to the crisis. The situation remains tense and unpredictable, with both sides showing no signs of a return to the brief lull that existed before the current flare-up.
answers: A brief, planned ceasefire failed to materialize in Gaza today, as death continued to rain down on the strip. Israel had offered to hold its offensive to accommodate a visit from Egyptian Prime Minister Hesham Kandil, provided Hamas held its fire as well. But Hamas said it would keep firing, and one Israeli defense minister complained that 50 rockets had flown in from Gaza during Kandil's visit, CNN reports. A Hamas-run TV station reported that Israel had kept firing as well, but Israel says it took a break for at least two hours. In Palestine the death toll has risen to 21, including 13 civilians, Reuters reports. Among those civilians were seven children and a pregnant teenager. Israel's death toll held steady at 3, despite the hundreds of rockets fired into Israel. But Hamas did up the ante by firing rockets near Tel Aviv for the first time. Air-raid sirens sounded (the last time they did so was during the Gulf War) and civilians ran for cover, though the missiles exploded harmlessly, with one going into the sea. "There will be a price for that escalation," Ehud Barak vowed, according to the New York Times. Israel has now hit 250 Gaza targets, while taking further steps toward a ground invasion, calling up 16,000 reservists, the Wall Street Journal reports. It's also steadily sending troops and armored vehicles to the border, notes CNN—between 1,500 and 2,000 are already there, one official said. Israel claims the attacks have weakened Hamas' military capabilities and caused its attacks to lighten, but Hamas denied that, saying it had hit multiple Israeli targets today. Kandil emerged from his meeting with Hamas expressing solidarity, saying the new Egyptian regime would be more active in helping the Palestinians. "The time has changed," he said. "No longer the Israeli occupation will be able to carry out their attacks against the Palestinians without being held responsible. That time is far bygone." For its part, the Obama administration says it's seeking help from Arab countries in calling on Hamas to relent. "The onus rests squarely on Hamas ... to stop its rocket attacks," says a State Department spokesman. UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-Moon is planning diplomatic visits to Jerusalem, Ramallah, and Cairo within days.

On June 3, Borch was jogging near her home when she encountered a rabid raccoon that lunged at her, biting her and scratching her with its paws. Despite the danger, she managed to hold the raccoon's head under water, using her bare hands to subdue it, after realizing it was the only way to stop the attack. The raccoon tested positive for rabies later, and Borch sought medical treatment, receiving shots and immunizations.

Another man, bitten by a suspected rabid fox in Topsham earlier in the season, also highlights the unpredictable nature of rabies in animals. The Maine Warden Service and the Maine Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) confirm that 20 animals, including raccoons, have tested positive for rabies in 2017, with 64 cases in 2016. This underscores the importance of avoiding contact with infected animals and seeking medical attention immediately if bitten.

These incidents serve as a reminder that rabies, although rare in humans, can be deadly if left untreated. It's crucial for pet owners to ensure their animals are vaccinated, and for individuals to be cautious around any wild animal behaving aggressively or displaying unusual behavior, as the virus can survive in the animal's saliva for up to 24 hours. Both Borch and the man who was bitten are recovering from their injuries and taking necessary precautions to prevent further infection.
answers: Rachel Borch was out for a jog in the woods near her home in Hope, Maine, when a "ferocious-looking" attacker with beady eyes and tiny teeth made a beeline for her, reports the Camden Herald. Borch, 21, knew immediately that something was wrong with the raccoon that was charging toward her. "Imagine the Tasmanian devil," she tells the Bangor Daily News of the "terrifying" June 3 incident. Yanking out her headphones, she began "dancing" around the animal on the narrow path, but she tells the Herald she knew that, one way or another, the animal was going to bite her. She figured her hands would be the best spot, so she offered them up. The raccoon chomped down on her thumb and stayed there, scratching at her legs and arms as she screamed. Now on her knees, she spotted her phone lying submerged in a mud puddle, and had an idea: drown it. "With my thumb in its mouth, I just pushed its head down into the muck," she tells the News. When the raccoon finally stopped moving, she yanked out her finger and raced the three-quarters of a mile home. Two days later, the state confirmed the animal was infected with rabies. Borch got rabies shots, and an animal control officer adds an unpleasant footnote: The infected raccoon may not be alone. "Not to scare people," Heidi Blood tells the News, but "when there’s one, there’s typically another." (Normally nocturnal like raccoons, a crazed beaver attacked a woman paddle-boarder.)

The recent discoveries in the field of planetary science have shed light on Mars' past, revealing a significant body of water that once covered a large portion of the planet's northern hemisphere. A study published in the journal Science indicates that a massive ancient ocean, comparable to Earth's Atlantic, covered nearly half of Mars' surface, with a depth of up to a mile, and held 20 million cubic kilometers of water. This ancient ocean, which persisted around 4.5 billion years ago, was a result of the detection of a high concentration of deuterium, or heavy hydrogen, in the Martian atmosphere.

NASA scientists used powerful telescopes to analyze the Martian atmosphere and discovered that the planet's water had a global equivalent water layer that was enriched in deuterium, with an average enrichment of about 8 times Earth's standard (VSMOW) value. This high D/H ratio suggests that Mars had a global ocean that was at least 137 meters deep, equivalent to 137 meters of water covering the entire planet. The process of water loss over time, as indicated by the increased deuterium concentration, indicates that Mars had a much wetter past than it is now.

The discovery of this ancient ocean challenges the previous understanding of Mars' water presence, which was previously believed to be sporadic and insufficient for creating long-lasting bodies of water. The presence of such a large body of water on Mars raises the possibility that the planet may have had a more habitable environment in its youth, fostering the idea that life could have existed there.

In addition to the ancient ocean, Mars is also being explored for signs of life, with the detection of methane on Mars by the Curiosity rover sparking speculation. However, the exact origin of the methane is not yet attributed to life, as it can also be produced by geological processes. The upcoming European Space Agency's Exomars rover, set to launch in 2018, aims to further investigate the planet's habitability by searching for chemical signatures of life.

Overall, these findings suggest that Mars had a more dynamic and potentially habitable past than previously thought, reigniting interest in the possibility of past life on the planet. However, the exact extent of that habitability and the likelihood of life remaining on Mars today remain open questions.
answers: Imagine all the water in the Arctic Ocean. Now, imagine all that and more on Mars. If you visited the Red Planet roughly 4.3 billion years ago, that's what you likely would have found, say NASA scientists. Their new study arrived at that "solid estimate ... by determining how much water was lost to space," says lead author Geronimo Villanueva. The Guardian reports the scientists used three powerful infrared telescopes to analyze two forms of water in Mars' atmosphere: H2O and HDO, in which deuterium (aka "heavy" hydrogen) has taken the place of one hydrogen atom. As National Geographic explains, Mars' gravity is weaker than our own; that allowed hydrogen to escape from the atmosphere and into space over time, boosting the amount of deuterium in its water. Scientists compared the ratio of HDO to H2O in Martian water today with that in water from a 4.5 billion-year-old Mars meteorite to arrive at their conclusions, a press release states. They ultimately calculated that Mars was once home to 20 million cubic kilometers of ocean. It could have covered every inch of the planet in water 450 feet deep, but the scientists think a different scenario is more likely: that the ocean covered roughly a fifth of the planet, was located in the northern hemisphere, and was as much as a mile deep. While National Geographic observes the findings back up "reams of earlier evidence that water once existed on the surface" of Mars, another study author points out the assessment of the degree of water lost indicates something new. "The planet was very likely wet for a longer period of time than was previously thought, suggesting it might have been habitable for longer," a scientist says. (Mysterious plumes on Mars are stumping scientists.)

In 2014, a student named Firas Jumaah, who was a member of the Yazidi ethnic group in Iraq, reached out to his Analytical Chemistry professor, Charlotta Turner, to inform her that he might not complete his thesis due to the danger he faced with the Islamic State (IS) in his hometown. Turner, upon hearing about the escalating situation, became determined to help Jumaah and his family. Jumaah had fled to Iraq to be with his family during a violent IS offensive, leaving his wife and children behind. Turner, concerned for Jumaah's well-being and the disruption to his research, contacted the university's security chief, Per Gustafson, who organized a daring rescue operation.

Gustafson hired a security company to arrange for the safe evacuation of Jumaah and his family from a disused bleach factory where they were hiding. Two Landcruisers, accompanied by heavily-armed mercenaries, successfully rescued them and transported them to Erbil Airport in Iraq.幸运的是，Jumaah's family survived the IS occupation, and he completed his PhD in Sweden before finding employment in a pharmaceuticals company in Malmö. The university, led by Turner, was the first to take such a significant step in aiding a student in this dire situation, and the rescue operation was considered a unique and unprecedented event.

This story highlights the resilience and courage of both Turner and Jumaah, as well as the university's commitment to its students' safety and well-being. Despite the challenges and risks, Turner's intervention and the university's assistance ultimately saved Jumaah and his family from the clutches of the Islamic State.
answers: Four years ago, a chemistry professor got a text from her grad student: If I'm not back in a week, cut me from the doctoral program. Charlotta Turner called him right away: "He was very sad and crying,” the 48-year-old prof at Lund University in Sweden tells NBC News. "I could hear that the situation was hopeless and they had to flee." The student, Firas Jumaah, was visiting his native Iraq to help family members during a brutal 2014 ISIS attack targeting Yazidis—a religious minority that includes his family. The terror group had just enslaved and massacred Yazidis by the thousand in nearby Sinjar. Now Jumaah and family were planning to flee to the mountains. "I had no hope at all," says Jumaah, per the Local. "I was desperate." But Turner took action. She spoke to Lund University's then-security chief, who contacted a company that sent mercenaries into northern Iraq. Only days later, four armed mercs on two Landcruisers blazed into the place where Jumaah was hiding, and rushed him to Erbil Airport with his wife and two young kids. "I have never felt so privileged, so VIP," he says. "But at the same time I felt like a coward as I left my mother and sisters behind me." Seeing his colleagues back in Sweden, he was speechless: "I just cried," he says. Yet Jumaah finished his PhD and found work at a Malmo pharmaceuticals company, and his family survived. The bill: roughly 60,000 kroner ($6,613), which his family has nearly finished paying. “If they told me to pay 200,000 kronor, I would,” says Jumaah. (The UN is finding fresh ISIS horrors.)

The news articles discuss the film "Focus," starring Will Smith and Margot Robbie, which has been criticized for its lack of authenticity and for failing to deliver on its promise of a secret underworld expose. The movie's premise revolves around a con artist and his apprentice, but reviewers find it absurd and devoid of substance. While the chemistry between Smith and Robbie is noted as a highlight, the film's weak emotional core and confusing plot are cited as drawbacks. Despite the star power, "Focus" is seen as a missed opportunity, with the potential to be a charming con on screen but ultimately falling short in its execution.

The article also mentions that the casting for the role was a rollercoaster, with many actresses considered for the part, including Jennifer Lawrence, Emma Stone, and Michelle Williams, but the final pairing of Will Smith and Margot Robbie proved successful. Smith's natural charm, as showcased in his earlier role as a conman in "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air," is compared to his performance in "Focus," where he plays a pickpocketing expert.

The film's director, John Requa and Glenn Ficarra, are praised for allowing Smith to showcase his charisma, which has been largely absent in his recent roles. The story of a con artist and his protege learning the tricks of the trade in a world of deception is a concept that could have been engaging, but the execution falls flat due to the lack of credibility.

A few scattered good moments and a light-hearted touch with some comedic scenes, particularly involving Adrian Martinez, are mentioned, but the film's central relationship between the characters is deemed unconvincing. Overall, "Focus" is described as a movie that relies on its cast's charm but fails to deliver a compelling narrative or a convincing portrayal of the con world it tries to depict.
answers: Will Smith stars as Nicky, an established con man who takes on a new apprentice, Australian newcomer Margot Robbie's Jess, in Focus. They both love the con game, but who's playing who? Here's what critics are saying: Richard Corliss at Time is a fan. "The mix of longtime star and minx on the rise is one tasty element in the success of a movie that approaches the modest goals and effortless allure of a 60-year-old Hitchcock," he writes. Smith "takes a welcome break from glowering sci-fi roles" and writer-directors Glenn Ficarra and John Requa "deserve some credit in letting Will be Will in the star's first charm barrage since 2005's Hitch." Steven Rea at the Philadelphia Inquirer admits Smith "shows some of the movie-star wattage that's been missing from his recent pics. He charms." There's also "combustible chemistry" between Smith and Robbie, but the movie just "disappoints," Rea writes. "Even if you're willing to forgive its sinkhole plotholes and farthest-fetched conceits, the film ... ultimately makes no sense." Betsy Sharkey, on the other hand, says this "rom-com-con" is "an irresistible reminder of all the reasons we first fell for the Fresh Prince so many years ago." Writing at the Los Angeles Times, she notes the romantic role of Nicky fits Smith perfectly, while Robbie is "more than holding her own" as his match. "The scams are Rubik's Cube complicated, but what keeps you guessing is whether the romantic connection between Jess and Nicky is real or just another con." But Mick LaSalle at the San Francisco Chronicle isn't convinced. In a review titled "Will Smith just stole $12 from your pocket," he argues Focus is "ridiculous in every detail. It's a movie with no truth that teaches nothing and shows nothing, that has only its audacity to recommend it." Nicky and Jess lack "impact," partly because "Smith is not a strong leading man," he says. Viewers are left "waiting for the trick, which is not the same as being fooled."

Statistical methods, particularly Bayesian inference, have been used to aid in the search for missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 and other lost objects, similar to the 2009 Air France Flight 447 case. Bayesian techniques help refine the search by calculating probabilities for each point in the search area, accounting for factors like ocean currents and wind patterns. These probabilities are initially based on assumptions, which can be updated as new information becomes available.

In the case of Air France Flight 447, Bayesian analysis was used to combine historical data and new information to determine the most likely location of the wreckage. The search for the missing plane involved multiple layers of complexity, with the likelihood of the plane being in the initial search area reduced due to new evidence suggesting a deliberate act.

The Bayesian approach, however, faces challenges when faced with significant changes in the situation, as highlighted by statistician Brad Efron. This is because the method relies on a "good" prior belief, which can be adjusted based on new evidence, but it may not be as effective when the situation changes drastically.

The search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 has been complicated by the possibility of a deliberate diversion, which affects the probability distribution of the plane's location. Bayesian statisticians are working with the French government's investigation team to use these methods, but the search has yet to yield a definitive result, and experts caution that the plane's location might not be found due to the vastness of the ocean.

In summary, Bayesian statistics, inspired by the work of Thomas Bayes, have proven useful in narrowing down search areas, but the complexity of the Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 case, with its possible hijacking, complicates the calculations. While Bayesian methods can provide a flexible and adaptable framework, they are not without limitations, especially when faced with significant changes in the situation. The search for the missing plane continues, but the chances of finding the entire aircraft intact are uncertain.
answers: Forget satellite images and aerial searches—the best way to find Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 may be with mathematical techniques dating back to the 18th century, the BBC reports. That's how Air France flight 447 was found in 2009, using "Bayesian statistics" to measure the probability of the plane being in one place or another. Named after Presbyterian minister and mathematician Thomas Bayes, the technique allowed experts to apply several factors to each point on a map: For example, what was the chance it crashed from mechanical failure? How far do planes tend to crash from their last known location? What was the chance that search teams missed debris in various locations? It's like picking a restaurant by balancing how full it is, what your favorite restaurant-review website says, and so on—except that experts hunting for Airbus A330 did that for each point where plane may have crashed in the Atlantic, Five Thirty-Eight notes. It was so hard that the US team of statisticians invited by France gave up, until they de-emphasized one statistic: that a plane's black box emits a signal after a crash 90% of the time. They changed their findings, and presto, the plane was found. Bayesian techniques have helped people find World War II U-boats, men overboard, and sunken treasure, but there's no evidence that Malaysia is employing them now. "I suspect that they just guess, like professional baseball managers used to do before Moneyball," says a biostatistician.

To witness the eclipse, people could tune in to the Virtual Telescope's live stream or observe the moon's appearance during moonrise and moonset, as it would remain bright and enlarged for a few days after the event. For the first time since 1866, a total lunar eclipse will occur with the blue moon, or second full moon of the month, which—like the one visible on New Year's Day—will also be a supermoon. Got all that? When the moon is at or near the closest point to Earth in its orbit (aka, a supermoon), it appears 14% bigger and 30% brighter than full moons that occur at the farthest point in the moon's orbit, though the moon will lose brightness as it enters Earth's shadow, according to NASA. Because of the way Earth's atmosphere bends light, the eclipsed moon will take on a reddish hue, something often referred to as a blood moon, making this rare celestial event "a super blue blood moon eclipse," according to the Miami Herald. The next blue moon eclipse won't occur until 2028. The eclipse will last for 3.5 hours, with the total eclipse stretching for 77 minutes, reports Sky & Telescope. Those along the Pacific Rim from Alaska and northwestern Canada to central and eastern Asia, Indonesia, New Zealand, and Australia will get the best view of totality during the middle of the night. However, partial phases of the eclipse should be visible under a clear sky in central North America, western Asia, India, the Middle East and eastern Europe, per Space.com. North American viewers should look up as the moon sets on the morning of Jan. 31, while those on the opposite side of the world should see a partial eclipse as the moon rises. Not in an ideal viewing area? The Virtual Telescope plans to livestream the total eclipse from Australia, which you can watch here, per Quartz. (Bogus glasses damaged a solar eclipse viewer's eyes.)
